headline: JM Financial bets on UltraTech, Ambuja & JK Cement amid cement sector revival
description: UltraTech Cement, Ambuja Cements, and JK Cement have received 'buy' ratings from JM Financial due to promising growth prospects amid sector recovery driven by infrastructure and housing initiatives. UltraTech is highlighted for its robust strategy, while Ambuja and JK Cement show significant upside potential. The industry's consolidation and cost optimization are set to enhance profitability over the coming years.
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

Amid a sector-wide revival for cement stocks driven by infrastructure growth and government housing initiatives, UltraTech Cement Ambuja Cements and JK Cement have emerged as top picks for brokerage firm JM Financial as it initiated coverage on five major cement stocks with ‘buy’ ratings, with a focus on their strong growth prospects, cost optimization strategies, and market leadership.JM Financial initiated coverage on UltraTech Cement , Ambuja Cements, JK Cement, ACC Ltd , and Birla Corporation , all of which received ‘buy’ ratings. Among them, UltraTech Cement stood out as the brokerage's top pick, praised for its pan-India presence, solid growth trajectory, and effective cost optimization strategies.According to JM Financial, the cement sector is positioned for significant recovery, supported by strong infrastructure growth, government housing initiatives, and urban housing revival. Demand in the industry is projected to grow at a 7-8% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) over fiscal 2025 to 2027, stabilizing utilization rates at around 72% during this period.UltraTech Cement is expected to deliver a 24% potential upside, with a target price of Rs 13,000 per share. The company’s leadership in green power adoption, logistics optimization, and nationwide expansion further bolsters its favorable outlook.Ambuja Cements follows with a target price of Rs 685, offering a potential gain of 32.8%. Meanwhile, JK Cement is expected to see a 20.8% upside, with a target price of Rs 5,300 per share. ACC and Birla Corporation also received ‘buy’ ratings, with the brokerage expressing confidence in their growth potential, backed by improving sector fundamentals.The brokerage shed light on the transformative phase in the cement sector, driven by government expenditure on infrastructure and housing. JM Financial highlighted consolidation efforts, particularly those spearheaded by Adani and UltraTech, which have introduced greater pricing discipline and the potential for sustained profitability gains.Industry profitability, which hit multi-quarter lows in FY25 due to weak demand and intense competition, is expected to recover significantly. JM Financial said it anticipates an EBITDA CAGR of over 25% for the sector over FY25-27, supported by a stable pricing environment and improved operational efficiency.The brokerage said the industry's focus is on cost optimization and de-risking, which is expected to mitigate cyclicality in the long term. JM Financial noted, "as a result, investors should look beyond short-term cement price fluctuations and focus on structural changes that are likely to drive long-term profitability."Despite the optimism, the brokerage attuned to a cautious tone regarding cement players in the South and East regions, which may face challenges due to aggressive capacity additions and intensified competition. Stocks like Shree Cement, Dalmia Bharat, and Star Cement have been assigned a "hold" rating, reflecting limited near-term upside potential.Also read | Up to 36% upside! Reliance Industries share target price from CLSA and 4 other foreign brokerages (Disclaimer: Recommendations, suggestions, views and opinions given by the experts are their own. These do not represent the views of Economic Times)

headline: Shree Cement Q2 FY25 results: Profit down 81% at Rs 93 crore YoY; revenue slips 18%
description: Shree Cement Q2: The company's revenue from operations fell 18 per cent (YoY) to Rs 3,727 crore from Rs 4,560 crore in the corresponding period last year. Operating profit (EBITDA) declined 32 per cent YoY to Rs 593 crore compared to Rs 870 core in Q2 FY24.
article_body:
Shree Cement Ltd on Monday recorded an 81 per cent year-on-year (YoY) slump in its September 2024 quarter (Q2 FY25) standalone net profit due to extended monsoon and softer pricing. During the quarter under review, profit came at Rs 93 crore as against Rs 491 crore in the year-ago period.

Related Articles

The company's revenue from operations fell 18 per cent (YoY) to Rs 3,727 crore from Rs 4,560 crore in the corresponding period last year. Operating profit (EBITDA) declined 32 per cent YoY to Rs 593 crore compared to Rs 870 core in Q2 FY24.

"Led by cost optimization and efficiency measures, total expenditure (excluding depreciation and interest) came down from Rs 4,503/tonne to Rs 4,122/tonne on (a) YoY basis," Shree Cement stated in a release.

Neeraj Akhoury, Managing Director at Shree Cement, said, "Despite strong headwinds on account of extended monsoon and softer pricing environment across the industry, Shree Cement has delivered a steady performance on the back of accelerated operational efficiency measures, focused cost optimisation drive and product premiumisation initiatives. The company expects gradual improvement in demand driven by increased government spending in the second half of the financial year and improved demand from urban and rural segments owing to good monsoon."

On capex plans, the company said its ongoing expansion projects in Jaitaran, Rajasthan (6.0 MTPA), Kodla, Karnataka (3.00 MTPA), Baloda Bazar, Chhattisgarh (3.40 MTPA), and Etah, Uttar Pradesh (3.00 MTPA) are progressing satisfactorily. It expects to commission all these projects by the first quarter of FY25-26.

The quarterly results were declared post market hours today. Earlier in the day, Shree Cement shares slipped 0.66 per cent to close at Rs 24,389.75. At this price, it has fallen 14.31 per cent in 2024 so far.

The counter saw high trading volume on BSE as around 539 shares changed hands. The figure was higher than the two-week average volume of 222 shares. Turnover on the counter came at Rs 1.31 crore, commanding a market capitalisation (m-cap) of Rs 88,107.56 crore.

Shree Cement shares traded lower than the 5-day, 10-, 20-, 30-, 50-, 100-, 150-day and 200-day simple moving averages (SMAs). The scrip's 14-day relative strength index (RSI) came at 40.66. A level below 30 is defined as oversold while a value above 70 is considered overbought.

According to BSE data, the company's stock has a price-to-equity (P/E) ratio of 40.17 against a price-to-book (P/B) value of 4.35. Earnings per share (EPS) stood at 611.14 with a return on equity (RoE) of 10.82.

As of September 2024, promoters held a 62.55 per cent stake in the company.

headline: Rs 50 Interim Dividend announced per share; record date Feb 5, payment date Feb 17
description: Rs 50 Dividend Announcement: A top cement company has announced to reward its investors by paying an interim dividend. The company has also fixed the dividend record date and dividend payment date.
article_body:
Authored by : ET Now Digital Updated Feb 1, 2025 11:04 IST Rs 50 Interim Dividend announced per share; record date on Feb 5 (Pic: ET NOW)

Rs 50 Dividend Announcement : A top cement company has announced to reward its investors by paying an interim A top cement company has announced to reward its investors by paying an interim dividend . The company has also fixed the dividend record date and dividend payment date.

The name of the cement company under discussion is Shree cement

"Board declared Interim dividend of Rs 50 per equity share of Rs 10 each for the Financial Year 2024-25," Shree Cement said in a regulatory filing.

"...the Record Date for payment of Interim Divided shall be Wednesday, 5th February, 2025," Shree Cement said in a filing.

Shree Cement has also fixed the dividend payment date. Shree Cement said that Rs 50 interim dividend will be paid to eligible shareholders from February 17.

"The dividend shall be paid from Monday, 17th February, 2025," according to an exchange filing by the company.

Shree Cement is a constituent of NIFTY NEXT 50 index.

As per exchange data, Shree Cement shares have slipped 9 per cent in the last one year and yielded a positive return of 10 per cent in two years.

Shree Cement shares have a 52-week range of Rs 30,737.75 - Rs 23,500 on NSE. Shree Cement has a market capitalisation of Rs 94,271.96 crore.

End of article

headline: Shree Cement MD Bets On Growth In Second Half On Cost-Cutting, Premiumisation Measures
description: Shree Cement MD Neeraj Akhoury says the second quarter was challenging due to excessive monsoon even as delayed capex softened demand.
article_body:
Shree Cement’s Ebitda for the quarter under review nosedived 30.8% YoY to Rs 613 crore from Rs 886 crore in the corresponding quarter of the last fiscal.

Despite the sharp decline, Akhoury is hopeful of a turnaround in the second half, on the back of enhanced focus on cost optimisation and premiumisation of the portfolio.

“We would try to give a lower cost versus previous quarters. We are hopeful that with the demand going up and our cost strategy working out, with a focus on premium products, we should see a better Ebitda in the next two quarters,” he said.

headline: CCI approves Ultratech Cement's acquisition of India Cements
description: UltraTech Cement got approval to acquire India Cements.  The deal expands UltraTech's presence in South India.  UltraTech bought a 32.72% stake for Rs 3,954 crore.  They also launched a Rs 3,142.35 crore open offer for another 26% stake.  UltraTech, India's largest cement producer, aims to reach 200 MTPA capacity.  India Cements has a 14.45 MTPA capacity.
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our Economic Times WhatsApp channel

The Competition Commission Of India on Friday approved UltraTech Cement 's acquisition of India Cements , the antitrust watchdog said in a post on social media platform X."The proposed combination envisages UltraTech Cement Ltd 's (UltraTech/acquirer) acquisition of 32.72 per cent of the paid-up equity share capital of India Cements Ltd (India Cements/target) from the promoters and members of the promoter group of India Cements and Sri Saradha Logistics Pvt Ltd," CCI said in a release.The fair trade regulator also granted its clearance to UltraTech Cement to acquire up to 26 per cent of the paid-up equity share capital of India Cements by way of an open offer, it added.Earlier, Aditya Birla Group flagship company UltraTech Cement announced that it will acquire a 32.72 per cent stake in India Cements from promoters and their associates in a Rs 3,954 deal to expand its footprint in the highly competitive and fast-growing Southern cement market, particularly Tamil Nadu. Besides, Ultratech has also announced a Rs 3,142.35 crore open offer to acquire another 26 per cent share of India Cements Ltd (ICL) from its shareholders.With an installed capacity of 154.86 million tonnes per annum (MTPA) of grey cement, UltraTech Cement leads the Indian cement industry. It has an ambition to become one of the largest cement companies in the world and and has set a target for 200 MTPA.In June, UltraTech acquired 23 per cent shares of ICL. It had acquired Damani-group's stake in India Cements Ltd (ICL) through two block deals estimated at around Rs 1,900 crore.ICL has a total Group capacity of 14.45 MTPA of grey cement. Of this, 12.95 MTPA is in the south, and 1.5 MTPA is in Rajasthan.(more to come)

headline: Shree Cement Q2 Results: Profit Down Over 80%, Misses Estimates
description: Shree Cement reports an 82.8% drop in Q2 FY25 profit to Rs 76.6 crore, falling short of analysts' estimates due to weak cement prices and reduced demand amid prolonged monsoon. Revenue and Ebitda also decline significantly.
article_body:
Shree Cement Ltd.'s consolidated net profit fell 82.8% in the second quarter of fiscal 2025, missing analysts' estimates.

The company's profit fell to Rs 76.6 crore in the quarter-ended Sept 30, 2024, according to an exchange filing on Monday. Analysts tracked by Bloomberg had set a consensus estimate of Rs 273.9 crore.

The company's earnings were mainly impacted by a weak cement pricing environment pan- India as well as a prolonged monsoon that impacted demand. Total sale volumes of Shree Cements fell 7% year on year during the quarter.

headline: Shree Cement to invest Rs 1,100cr to set up cement plant, solar power project
description: Patna: Rajasthan-based Shree Cement will invest Rs 1,100 crore in Bihar to set up a cement plant and solar power project in Purnea district, its chair.
article_body: Patna: Rajasthan-based Shree Cement will invest Rs 1,100 crore in Bihar to set up a cement plant and solar power project in Purnea district, its chairman H M Bangur said on Friday. The Bangur family-promoted company is among the top five cement producers in the country. "We have signed an MoU with the Bihar govt to invest Rs 800 crore. We will be setting up a cement plant in north-east Bihar with an annual capacity of 2 million tonnes," Bangur told PTI on the sidelines of Bihar Business Connect 2024. "We will also be investing Rs 300 crore to set up a solar plant. We have not signed MoU for the solar power plant," Bangur said. Both cement and solar plants will be set up in Purnia district, he added.

headline: Possible breather for Shree Cement as RoC flags no major concerns: Sources
description: In a breather for Shree Cement, sources say the RoC report flags no major governance issues. The MCA's DG Investigations will now review the findings before a final submission.
article_body:
₹7,000 crore for solid waste management, though no such utility was found at any company premises.



₹250 crore for a water treatment plant, though investigations revealed only an RO water unit for employee use, with no treatment plant installed.



Deductions under the New India Power Undertaking Scheme, despite only repurposing old machinery for a power plant already claimed for deductions earlier.



In what could be a breather for Shree Cement, sources say the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) has received the inspection report from the Registrar of Companies (RoC) on the cement major.Sources indicate that the “inspection report does not highlight any major corporate governance issues at the company. The Directorate General of Investigations (DGI) at MCA will now assess the RoC report before making a formal submission to the ministry on Shree Cement.”The MCA had ordered a probe into Shree Cement after the Income Tax (I-T) Department conducted a survey at various locations of the company in mid-2023.The I-T Department had raised a claim of ₹4,000 crore against Shree Cement, which includes tax dues, interest, and penalties for alleged wrongful claims and deductions.Senior government officials earlier revealed, “The I-T Department, following its survey, found that Shree Cement had raised wrongful deductions under Section 80-IA of the Income Tax Act.”The survey, conducted in June 2023, covered five locations of the company, including Beawar, Jaipur, Chittorgarh, and Ajmer. The deductions in question pertain to the period between April 2014 and March 2023.These findings were described as major violations, raising concerns about the company’s compliance practices.

headline: Shree Cement Ras facility earns NABL accreditation
description: Shree Cement Ras facility earns NABL accreditation
article_body: India: Shree Cement's Ras quality control laboratory in Rajasthan has been recognised by the National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories (NABL), affirming its compliance with the ISO/IEC 17025:2017 standards. Managing Director Neeraj Akhoury said that the accreditation acknowledges the company's commitment to providing premium, sustainable building materials. The laboratory's role in ensuring standardisation across all product testing is important for maintaining production quality at the plant.

headline: Shree Cement announces Q3’FY25 results, Strong 60% quarterly EBITDA growth led by robust performance on cost and price levers
description: Bengaluru  – Shree Cement, India’s third largest cement group by capacity, today announced its financial results for the quarter and nine months ended on 31st December, 2024. The Company reported ₹ 4,235 crore of revenue and ₹ 947 crore of EBITDA. Financial Highlight (Standalone) Operational highlights (Standalone) •            Total sale…
article_body:
Bengaluru – Shree Cement, India’s third largest cement group by capacity, today announced its financial results for the quarter and nine months ended on 31st December, 2024. The Company reported ₹ 4,235 crore of revenue and ₹ 947 crore of EBITDA.

Financial Highlight (Standalone)

Operational highlights (Standalone)

• Total sale volumes up by 15% from 7.60 million tonnes to 8.77 million tonnes on QoQ basis

• Power & fuel cost optimized by 9% to ₹913 crore v/s ₹ 1,001 crore in Q2’FY25 due to softer fuel prices and operational efficiency

• EBITDA jumped to ₹947 crore from ₹ 593 crore on QoQ basis

• Led by cost optimization and efficiency measures, total expenditure (excluding depreciation and interest) came down from ₹4,122/ tonne to ₹3,748/ tonne on QoQ basis

• Sales of premium products stood at 15.0% of trade sale volume vs 14.9% in Q2’FY25

Commenting on the company’s performance for the quarter, Mr. Neeraj Akhoury, Managing Director of Shree Cement Ltd., stated, “Our strategy of prioritizing premium, high value products coupled with sharp focus on brand enhancement, strengthening the dealer network and optimizing the geo-mix has enabled us to improve our sale volumes. The results of our continued emphasis on operational excellence, efficiency improvements, and cost optimization are evident in our streamlined production costs this quarter. Looking ahead, we remain committed to increasing the volume of our premium product offerings and maintaining our relentless focus on further cost optimization.”

Capex Plans

The Company’s ongoing expansion projects in Jaitaran, Rajasthan (6.0 MTPA), Kodla, Karnataka (3.00 MTPA), Baloda Bazar, Chhattisgarh (3.40 MTPA), and Etah, Uttar Pradesh (3.00 MTPA) are

nearing completion. The Company expects to commission all these projects in the first quarter of FY25-26. The Company is continuously working to identify suitable opportunities to achieve its goal of achieving > 80 MTPA capacity by 2028.

Sustainability initiatives

In Q3 FY’25, the Company continued its efforts to improve its performance regarding its commitment to operational excellence and sustainable growth. Key highlights are:

• The Company’s share of green electricity in total electricity consumption stood at 55.1% in Q3’FY25 which is one of the highest in the Indian cement industry. The Company is consistently ramping up its green power generation capacity which stood at 522 MW at the end of Q3’FY25, up by 9% vis-à-vis 480 MW at the beginning of the FY24-25.

• The Company used 0.24 lakh tonnes of agro waste in its cement operations to conserve fossil fuel equivalent to producing 71 billion kCal and saving 0.28 lakh tonnes of CO2. As part of this agro waste consumption, the Company procured 7,130 tonnes of stubble during the quarter for its operations within the NCR region. The Company also consumed 1.04 lakh tonnes of hazardous waste during Q3’FY25, replacing the fossil fuel-based heat by 50.4 billion kCal.

• All the Company’s manufacturing locations are Zero Liquid Discharge, treating, recycling, and reusing 100% of wastewater generated from our operations. With a good monsoon this year, the Company aims to improve its water positively level of >7 times achieved in FY23-24.

• During the quarter, the Company commenced operations of its state-of-the-art, end-to-end solid waste feeding system for municipal solid waste consumption at one of its locations and this is being replicated at other plants also. This initiative shall help us enhance proportion of alternative fuel consumption and improve TSR level.

Dividend

The Board of Directors, in today’s meeting, declared an interim dividend of ₹50/- per share (500%) for the year 2024-25.

Cement market outlook

We expect the cement demand to grow on the back of likely increase in rural consumption aided by improved farm cash flows, sustained healthy demand for urban housing and expected increase in government spending on infrastructure projects. This augurs well for the cement industry going forward.

headline: Shree Cement (NSE:SHREECEM) Has Affirmed Its Dividend Of ₹50.00
description: Shree Cement Limited ( NSE:SHREECEM ) will pay a dividend of ₹50.00 on the 17th of February. This means the dividend...
article_body:
Shree Cement Limited ( ) will pay a dividend of ₹50.00 on the 17th of February. This means the dividend yield will be fairly typical at 0.4%.

Shree Cement's Projected Earnings Seem Likely To Cover Future Distributions

We like to see a healthy dividend yield, but that is only helpful to us if the payment can continue. Based on the last payment, Shree Cement was earning enough to cover the dividend, but free cash flows weren't positive. With the company not bringing in any cash, paying out to shareholders is bound to become difficult at some point.

Over the next year, EPS is forecast to expand by 127.2%. If the dividend continues on this path, the payout ratio could be 15% by next year, which we think can be pretty sustainable going forward.

Shree Cement Has A Solid Track Record

The company has an extended history of paying stable dividends. Since 2015, the annual payment back then was ₹22.00, compared to the most recent full-year payment of ₹105.00. This means that it has been growing its distributions at 17% per annum over that time. So, dividends have been growing pretty quickly, and even more impressively, they haven't experienced any notable falls during this period.

Dividend Growth May Be Hard To Achieve

Investors could be attracted to the stock based on the quality of its payment history. However, initial appearances might be deceiving. Over the past five years, it looks as though Shree Cement's EPS has declined at around 2.4% a year. If the company is making less over time, it naturally follows that it will also have to pay out less in dividends. Earnings are forecast to grow over the next 12 months and if that happens we could still be a little bit cautious until it becomes a pattern.

In Summary

Overall, it's nice to see a consistent dividend payment, but we think that longer term, the current level of payment might be unsustainable. With cash flows lacking, it is difficult to see how the company can sustain a dividend payment. Overall, we don't think this company has the makings of a good income stock.

Investors generally tend to favour companies with a consistent, stable dividend policy as opposed to those operating an irregular one. At the same time, there are other factors our readers should be conscious of before pouring capital into a stock. For example, we've picked out that investors should know about before committing capital to this stock. Is Shree Cement not quite the opportunity you were looking for? Why not check out our

headline: Shree Cement to invest Rs 800 cr to set up cement plant in Bihar
description: Shree Cement, based in Rajasthan, will invest Rs 800 crore to set up a cement plant in North-East Bihar with an annual capacity of 2 million tonnes. The company signed an MoU with the Bihar government during the Bihar Business Connect 2024 summit.
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our Economic Times WhatsApp channel

Rajasthan-based Shree Cement will invest Rs 800 crore in Bihar to set up a cement plant, its Chairman H M Bangur said on Friday. The Bangur family-promoted company is among the top five cement producers in the country."We have signed an MoU with the Bihar government to invest Rs 800 crore. We will be setting up a cement plant in North-East Bihar with an annual capacity of 2 million tonnes," H M Bangur told PTI on the sidelines of Bihar Business Connect 2024.The Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed on the second day of the Bihar Business Connect 2024, a global investors summit.Shree Cement has an installed capacity of 46.9 Million Tonnes Per Annum in India and 50.9 including overseas.The Rajasthan-based group has ongoing expansion projects in Jaitaran, Rajasthan (6 MTPA), Kodla, Karnataka (3 MTPA), Baloda Bazar, Chhattisgarh (3.40 MTPA), and Etah, Uttar Pradesh (3 MTPA).Shree Cement has brands such as Roofon, Bangur Power, Shree Jung Rodhak, Bangur Cement and Rockstrong. It had a revenue of Rs 19,585.53 crore in FY'24.

headline: Shree Cement Q2 Results: Profit plunges 83% YoY to Rs 76 crore; revenue down 15%
description: Shree Cement Q2 Results: Net profit stood at Rs 447 crore in the year-ago quarter.  Despite challenging demand due to prolonged monsoons and softer prices, the company stated that its focus on brand equity, product premiumization, and improved geo-mix helped sustain its realization on a QoQ basis.
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

Shree Cement Ltd on Monday reported an 83% fall in its consolidated net profit for the quarter ended September 2024 to Rs 76 crore. The same stood at Rs 447 crore in the year-ago quarter.Revenue from operations in the reporting period declined 15% YoY to Rs 4,054 crore.Operating EBITDA during the quarter declined 32% YoY to Rs 593 crore as against Rs 870 crore in the same quarter last year.Despite the challenging demand conditions on account of prolonged monsoon and softer prices faced by the industry, the company said its focus on maintaining brand equity, product premiumization and improving geo-mix helped maintain its realisation on QoQ basis.This coupled with cost optimization and operational efficiency measures drove EBITDA during the quarter.Total sale volumes were down by 7% to 7.60 million tonnes in the quarter ended September 2024 on a YoY basis.Power and fuel costs optimized by 27% from Rs 1,001 crore due to softer fuel prices. Led by cost optimization and efficiency measures, total expenditure (excluding depreciation and interest) came down to Rs 4,122 per tonne in the second quarter.The company expects gradual improvement in demand driven by increased government spending in the second half of the financial year and improved demand from urban and rural segments owing to good monsoon.Shree Cement said it remains focused on its long-term growth and sustainability, with ongoing investments in capacity expansion and the adoption of greener technologies.The company’s ongoing expansion projects in Jaitaran, Rajasthan (6 MTPA), Kodla, Karnataka (3 MTPA), Baloda Bazar, Chhattisgarh (3.4 MTPA), and Etah, Uttar Pradesh (3. MTPA) are progressing satisfactorily. It expects to commission all these projects by the first quarter of FY25-26.The company said it is continuously working to identify suitable opportunities to meet its target of achieving over 80 MTPA capacity by 2028.On Monday, Shree Cement shares closed 0.45% lower at Rs 24,423 on the NSE.

headline: Shree Cement: It is important that corporates begin their transition to 24/7 carbon-free electricity as soon as possible.
description: Earlier this year Shree Cement joined Climate Group’s RE100 campaign, making a commitment to sourcing 100% renewable electricity for all its operations by 2050.
article_body:
Leading innovation and sustainability in the cement sector

While the production process of cement has historically been energy-intensive, the cement industry is embracing innovative solutions to enhance its environmental performance, of which utilising carbon-free electricity sources is a key pillar.

Shree Cement has achieved several industry-first milestones that reflect its commitment to a greener future, including publishing its first sustainability report 20 years ago (2004-05). This was the first within the Indian cement industry. The organisation’s efforts have been widely recognised, including being named the first Sustainability Champion by the World Economic Forum in 2011. Now, Shree Cement are demonstrating their continued commitment by joining Climate Group’s 24/7 Carbon-Free Coalition as a Founding Partner.

Renewable energy transition

headline: Shree Cement Q2 Results: Profit plunges over 80% to Rs 93 crore on weak demand, prices
description: Shree Cement reported a significant drop in profit for the September quarter. The company's profit fell by over 80% compared to the same period last year. This decline was attributed to weak demand and lower prices for cement. Shree Cement's sales volume also decreased by 7% during the quarter.
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

Kolkata-based Shree Cement ’s profit plunged more than 80% on year to Rs 93.13 crore in the September quarter, weighed down by weakness in both demand and prices for the building material during the three-month period.While the September quarter is seasonally weak for cement-makers, the country’s third largest producer’s sales volume slipped as compared to the previous year as well - 7% lower at 7.60 million tonne.“Despite strong headwinds on account of extended monsoon and softer pricing environment across the industry, Shree Cement has delivered a steady performance on the back of accelerated operational efficiency measures, focused cost optimisation drive and product premiumisation initiatives,” managing director Neeraj Akhoury said in a statement.The company’s net revenue from operations fell 18% on year to Rs 3,727 crore, while earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization fell 32% on year to Rs 593 crore.As compared to the June quarter, Shree Cement’s net revenue fell 23%, its EBITDA was 35% lower, while profit slumped 71%.“In the second half of FY24-25, an uptick in demand is expected on account of the release of budgetary allocations and on-ground execution of the infra projects. Further, higher rural demand is expected on the back of good kharif crop and improved farm prices,” the company said in its outlook.“Spending under additional houses in the PMAY scheme (rural and urban) and increase in industrial & commercial capex is also expected to drive cement demand in the near future,” it said.Shree Cement currently has a production capacity of nearly 47 million tonne, and aims to increase this to more than 80 million tonne by 2028. It is currently expanding capacities at Jaitaran in Rajasthan, Kodla in Karnataka, Baloda Bazar in Chhattisgarh and Etah in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Shree Cement Q2 beats the Street despite steep drop in net profit
description: Shree Cement Q2 Results | The EBITDA margin stood at 15.9% compared to 17.1% in the prior-year period, just about meeting projections. Shares of Shree Cement Ltd ended at ₹24,389.75, up by ₹162.15, or 0.66%, on the BSE.
article_body: Bangur family-promoted Shree Cement Ltd on Monday (November 11) reported an 81% year-on-year (YoY) decline in net profit at ₹93.1 crore for the second quarter that ended September 30, 2024.In the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal, Shree Cement posted a net profit of ₹491.3 crore, the company said in a regulatory filing. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a profit of ₹80 crore for the quarter under review.The company's revenue from operations tanked 18.3% to ₹3,727 crore against ₹4,585 crore in the year-ago period. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a revenue of ₹3,910 crore for the quarter under review.At the operating level, EBITDA dropped 32% to ₹592.6 crore in the second quarter of this fiscal over ₹870 crore in Q2 of FY24. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted an EBITDA of ₹620 crore for the quarter under review.The EBITDA margin stood at 15.9% in the reporting quarter as compared to 17.1% in the prior-year period. EBITDA is earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a margin of 15.9% for the quarter under review."Despite the challenging demand conditions on account of prolonged monsoon and softer prices faced by the industry, the Company’s focus on maintaining brand equity, product premiumization and improving geo-mix helped maintain its realisation on a QoQ basis. This coupled with cost optimization and operational efficiency measures drove EBITDA during the quarter," Shree Cement said.The cement major reported a 7% YoY decline in total sales volumes, down from 8.20 million tonnes (MT) to 7.60 MT in the quarter ended September, 2024. Cost efficiencies and softer fuel prices helped the company optimise its power and fuel expenses by 27%, which dropped from ₹1,371 crore to ₹1,001 crore.Through cost optimisation and efficiency measures, total expenditure per tonne (excluding depreciation and interest) fell to ₹4,122, down from ₹4,503 YoY. Sales of premium products represented 15% of the total trade sale volume for the quarter.The company's ongoing expansion projects in Jaitaran, Rajasthan (6 MTPA), Kodla, Karnataka (3 MTPA), Baloda Bazar, Chhattisgarh (3.40 MTPA), and Etah, Uttar Pradesh (3 MTPA) are progressing satisfactorily. The company expects to commission all these projects by the first quarter of FY25-26.The results came after the close of the market hours. Shares of Shree Cement Ltd ended at ₹24,389.75, up by ₹162.15, or 0.66%, on the BSE.

headline: Shree Cement shares fall 4% after Q2 results disappoint. Should you invest?
description: Shree Cements shares fell 4% on Tuesday to Rs 23,500.15 after the company reported an 80% YoY drop in Q2 profit, down to Rs 93.13 crore. The decline was driven by weak demand and lower prices for cement. Despite the seasonally slow quarter, sales volume also dropped 7% to 7.60 million tonnes.
article_body:
After the second quarter results, here is what analysts say:



HDFC Securities: Add | Target price: Rs 26,700



Motilal Oswal: Neutral | Target price: Rs 23,910



Nuvama: Hold | Target price: Rs 25,437







(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

Shares of Shree Cement dropped 4% on Tuesday to an intraday low of Rs 23,500.15 on the BSE after the Kolkata-based company’s Q2 profit plunged more than 80% on year to Rs 93.13 crore.The profit was weighed down by weakness in both demand and prices for the building material during the three months.While the September quarter is seasonally weak for cement makers, the country’s third-largest producer’s sales volume slipped as compared to the previous year as well - 7% lower at 7.60 million tonnes.The company’s net revenue from operations fell 18% on year to Rs 3,727 crore, while earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization fell 32% on year to Rs 593 crore.The fuel cost is expected to gradually cool off by 12% from Q2FY25 levels in the next three quarters. The company expects a Capex of Rs 4,000 crore each year for the next four years. Management plans to commission 14mn MT cement capacity in Q1FY26 to reach 70mn MT.Cement NSR fell only 0.4% QoQ, lower vs peers owing to a rise in trade sakes QoQ. Unit opex went up 2% QoQ, mainly on op-lev loss. Thus, unit EBITDA fell INR 170/MT QoQ to INR 780 per MT (down INR 280/ MT YoY.A few strategic changes, such as a focus on brand equity and product premiumization, are near-term hurdles in gaining market share despite capacity expansions.The company reinstated a few previous brands, such as Roofon, under the premium category, and Shree Jungrodhak under the master brand Bangur, which also led to uncertainties over the company’s marketing strategies. Motilal Oswal continues to believe most of the company’s expansions focus on existing markets (North, East, and part of South), while a large part of Central India and West will remain untapped until FY27E.The company’s capex plan shall help deliver sustained volume growth while cost efficiency measures would allow it to sustain cost leadership in the cement industry. However, the weak pricing environment compels us to slash FY25E/26E/27E EBITDA by 9%/6%/5%.: Recommendations, suggestions, views and opinions given by the experts are their own. These do not represent the views of Economic Times)

headline: Shree Cement Q1 Results: Profit Down 51%, Misses Estimates
description: Shree Cement Ltd.'s consolidated net profit fell 51.4% in the first quarter of fiscal 2025, missing analysts' estimates. The company's profit fell to Rs 278 crore in the quarter-ended June 30, 2024, according to an exchange filing on Tuesday. Analysts tracked by Bloomberg had set a consensus estimate of Rs 510 crore.
article_body:
Shree Cement Ltd.'s consolidated net profit fell 51.4% in the first quarter of fiscal 2025, missing analysts' estimates.

The company's profit fell to Rs 278 crore in the quarter-ended June 30, 2024, according to an exchange filing on Tuesday. Analysts tracked by Bloomberg had set a consensus estimate of Rs 510 crore.

One of the main factors that impacted the cement maker's Q1 earnings were higher depreciation and amortisation expenses, which more than doubled to Rs 704.26 crore, compared to Rs 339.45 crore a year ago.

headline: Shree Cement Q2 Profit Plunges 83% to Rs 77 cr | News
description: Shree Cement's Q2 profit plummeted 83% to Rs 77 crore due to challenging demand conditions caused by prolonged monsoon and lower prices. Revenue also dropped 15%.
article_body:
Shree Cement Q2 Profit Plunges 83% to Rs 77 cr | News

Share on:

By Rediff Money Desk, New Delhi Nov 11, 2024 16:50

Shree Cement's Q2 profit plummeted 83% to Rs 77 crore due to challenging demand conditions caused by prolonged monsoon and lower prices. Revenue also dropped 15%.

Photograph: Amit Dave/Reuters

New Delhi, Nov 11 (PTI) Bangur family-promoted Shree Cement Ltd on Monday reported 82.83 per cent decline in consolidated net profit at Rs 76.64 crore for September quarter FY25 as it faced challenging demand conditions on account of prolonged monsoon and lower price in the segment.



The company had logged a net profit of Rs 446.62 crore in the July-September period a year ago, according to a regulatory filing from Shree Cement Ltd (SCL).



Revenue from operations was down 15.07 per cent year-on-year to Rs 4,054.17 crore during the quarter.



Like other cement makers, SCL also faced "challenging demand conditions on account of prolonged monsoon and softer prices faced by the industry," the company said in its earning statement.



EBITDA stood at Rs 593 crore against Rs 870 crore in the corresponding quarter of the previous year.



Total expense was at Rs 4,212.27 crore, down 3.52 per cent from the year-ago period. Total sale volumes came down by 7 per cent to 7.60 million tonne as against 8.20 million tonne.



Total income, which includes other income, was also down 13.65 per cent to Rs 4,235.55 crore in the September quarter.



"Despite strong headwinds on account of extended monsoon and softer pricing environment across the industry, Shree Cement has delivered a steady performance on the back of accelerated operational efficiency measures, focused cost optimisation drive and product premiumisation initiatives, Managing Director Neeraj Akhoury said.



Over the outlook, he said SCL expects gradual improvement in demand driven by increased government spending in the second half of the financial year and improved demand from urban and rural segments owing to good monsoon.



"Shree Cement remains focused on its long-term growth and sustainability, with ongoing investments in capacity expansion and the adoption of greener technologies, he said.



Shares of SCL on Monday settled at Rs 24,389.75 apiece on BSE, down 0.66 per cent from the previous close.

headline: Shree Cement Q1 results: June quarter profit dips 45% and margin improves slightly
description: Shree Cement Q1 results: The cement maker's net profit at ₹318 crore for the first quarter of the FY25 fiscal was over 45% lower than what it recorded in the preceding quarter. It is also 46% less than the CNBC-TV18 poll projection of ₹589 crore.
article_body:
26,448.05 on NSE at 2:12 pm.

Shree Cement has reported its results for the April to June 2024 quarter in which it missed CNBC-TV18 poll estimates across parameters, mostly by a big margin, the financial results released on August 6 show.While the profit after tax (PAT) for the quarter has nearly halved on a sequential basis, its revenue and EBITDA have also declined from the March 2024 quarter levels. The margin, however, has improved slightly amid lower power and fuel expenses though other expenses were high.Shree Cement's revenue in Q1 slipped over 3.% lower on a sequential basis to ₹4,835 crore compared to ₹4,999 crore in the March 2024 quarter.The cement maker's net profit of ₹318 crore for the first quarter of the FY25 fiscal was over 45% lower than what it recorded in the preceding quarter. It is also 46% less than the CNBC-TV18 poll projection of ₹589 crore.During the quarter under review, the firm’s realizations were very weak and other expenses were sharply higher. The profit after tax (further) has been hit by higher depreciation, which rose 108%.On the operating level, EBITDA or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation fell more than a percent on a quarter-on-quarter basis to ₹917 crore. The margin, meanwhile, improved by 30 basis points to come in at 19% for the quarter.The company’s volumes went up 8% at 9.6 mt, which is in line with analysts’ expectations. In its statement, the cement maker said, the sale of premium products stood at 7.6% of total trade sale volume.In the result statement, Neeraj Akhoury, Managing Director of Shree Cement said, “We continued to optimize our production processes, enhance cost efficiencies and maintain a strong focus on branding initiatives. These efforts enabled us to navigate the challenging market conditions marked by sluggish demand due to general elections and extreme weather, consistently delivering value to our stakeholders.”He added that the company will continue to focus on increasing cement manufacturing capacity to gain market share.During the quarter, the company commissioned its integrated cement unit in the Guntur district of Andhra Pradesh with a cement production capacity of 3 million tonnes per annum (MTPA). Besides this, the company’s ongoing expansion projects in Jaitaran, Rajasthan (6.0 MTPA), Kodla, Karnataka (3.00 MTPA), Baloda Bazar, Chhattisgarh (3.40 MTPA), and Etah, Uttar Pradesh (3.00 MTPA) are progressing “satisfactorily” as per schedule.Shree Cement shares traded 1.4% lower at ₹

headline: Shree Cement posts net profit of Rs 76.64 crore in Q2 FY25
description: Shree Cement's net consolidated total income stood at Rs 4,235.55 crore in Q2 FY25, a dip of 13.66 per cent from Rs 4,905.62 crore it reported in the similar quarter last year.
article_body:
Advt

By ,

ETRealty

Join the community of 2M+ industry professionals Subscribe to our newsletter to get latest insights & analysis. Download ETRealty App Get Realtime updates

Save your favourite articles Scan to download App

NEW DELHI: Shree Cement has reported net consolidated profit after tax of Rs 76.64 crore in the quarter ended September 30, 2024. Its profit after tax stood at Rs 446.62 crore in the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal, the company said in a BSE filing.The company's net consolidated total income stood at Rs 4,235.55 crore in Q2 FY25, a dip of 13.66 per cent from Rs 4,905.62 crore it reported in the similar quarter last year. Neeraj Akhoury , managing director of the company said, "The company expects gradual improvement in demand driven by increased government spending in the second half of the financial year and improved demand from urban and rural segments owing to good monsoon."Total sale volumes were down by 7% from 8.20 million tonnes to 7.60 million tonnes year-on-year basis and total expenditure came down from Rs 4,503 per tonne to Rs 4,122 per tonne year-on-year basis during the said quarter.As on September 30, 2024, its net worth stood at Rs 20,879.28 crore, debt-equity ratio was 0.04, current liability ratio was 85%, total debts to total assets was 5%, operating margin was 20% and net profit margin was 2%.

headline: What triggered a sharp surge in Cement shares on Monday — Explained
description: Jefferies said that the industry is pencilling in a year-on-year volume growth of 8% to 10% in the second half of the current financial year, as a recovery might be seen in the March quarter due to a revival in government capex.
article_body:
Stock EV / Tonne ($) UltraTech 211 Shree Cement 138 JK Cement 139 Ramco Cement 110 Dalmia Bharat 88 Nuvoco 77 Birla Corp 67 Heidelberg 85 JK Lakshmi 67

Shares of Cement companies, right from UltraTech, to JK Lakshmi Cement, JK Cement, Mangalam Cement and even Shree Cement saw healthy gains during Monday's trading session. The stocks gained between 4% to as high as 9%, with UltraTech ending the session as the top gainer on the Nifty 50 index.Brokerage firm Jefferies in a note on Monday, mentioned that the cement industry is attempting price hikes every month, and is targeting a price hike between ₹10 to ₹15 per bag in the month of December.Prices in November were flat and in the third quarter so far, prices have gone up by 1.5% to 2% compared to the second quarter.Jefferies wrote in its note that dealer interactions indicate that price declines have bottomed out. The brokerage also said that the industry is pencilling in a year-on-year volume growth of 8% to 10% in the second half of the current financial year, as a recovery might be seen in the March quarter due to a revival in government capex.Petcoke prices in November have averaged at $95 per tonne, a slight growth seen on a month-on-month basis. Yet, they have remained below the $100 per tonne level seen until September this year. For the third quarter so far, average spot prices are down 12% sequentially and 26% year-on-year.However, industry veteran and Shree Digvijay Cement's Anil Singhvi said that he expects only 3% to 4% cement demand growth for the current financial year and he is not witnessing any big price increases yet.

headline: Shree Cement Leads with Solar and Wind Energy Projects
description: Shree Cement received accolades for three of its pioneering renewable energy installations: a 20 MWp Solar Plant in Beawar, Rajasthan; a 31.5 MW Wind Plant in Kushtagi, Karnataka; and a 10.5 MW Wind Plant in Jath, Maharashtra. Sectors
article_body:
Shree Cement, one of India’s leading and fastest-growing cement companies, has been awarded the prestigious CII Performance Excellence Awards 2024 for its innovative solutions in renewable energy at its Solar, Wind and Hybrid Plants. The awards were presented during the valedictory function of the 23rd Edition of the Green Power Conference, CII’s flagship event on renewable energy, held in Chennai.

Shree Cement received accolades for three of its pioneering renewable energy installations: a 20 MWp Solar Plant in Beawar, Rajasthan; a 31.5 MW Wind Plant in Kushtagi, Karnataka; and a 10.5 MW Wind Plant in Jath, Maharashtra. These projects exemplify the company’s commitment to sustainable energy solutions and innovative practices.

Commenting on the achievement, Neeraj Akhoury, Managing Director, Shree Cement said, "This recognition reflects our relentless efforts to integrate sustainability into every aspect of our operations. At Shree Cement, we believe that renewable energy is not just a responsibility but a crucial step towards building a better future. These awards reaffirm our commitment to innovation and our drive to contribute meaningfully to India’s renewable energy goals. We are proud of our team’s dedication and will continue to lead with initiatives that make a positive impact on the environment and the communities we serve."

The awards were presented by distinguished dignitaries, including Beela Rajesh, IAS, Principal Secretary to the Government (Department of Energy, Tamil Nadu); Ramesh Kymal, Chairman, Renewable Energy Council (CII – Godrej GBC); K S Venkatagiri, Executive Director, CII – Godrej GBC; and Dr. P Jayakumar, Chairman of the CII Performance Excellence Awards.

Shree Cement demonstrates its commitment to sustainability with a power portfolio exceeding 1 GW, including 517 MW from green energy. In FY 2023-24, 55.9% of its electricity needs were met through green sources. Key initiatives include a 20 MWp solar plant in Beawar, Rajasthan and wind plants in Kushtagi, Karnataka (31.5 MWp) and Jath, Maharashtra (10.5 MWp), collectively reducing CO2 emissions by nearly 98,000 tons annually. These plants significantly power its Beawar, Ras, Kodla and Patas units with renewable energy, reaffirming Shree Cement's leadership in green energy adoption.

Shree Cement has been at the forefront of implementing measures to reduce its environmental footprint. With around 51% of its electricity generation capacity comprising of green sources, the company has adopted cutting-edge technologies and practices to enhance energy efficiency. The company’s water positivity stood more than 7 times during FY 23-24, verified by an independent agency. This was a result of the water conservation and rain water harvesting initiatives implemented across its operational locations and community. A few water conservation measures include the installation of Air Cooled Condensers (ACC), which have reduced cooling water consumption by 90%, and utilizing municipal treated sewage water for industrial use and greenbelt development.

The company’s renewable energy installations, coupled with its industry-leading innovative approaches, underscore its commitment to sustainability while setting benchmarks in green energy adoption. As Shree Cement moves forward with its vision to expand production capacity to 80 million tonnes by 2028, it remains steadfast in its pursuit of a cleaner, greener future.

headline: Shree Cement Q1 Profit Down 51.3% to Rs 278.45 Crore
description: Shree Cement's consolidated net profit declined by 51.31% to Rs 278.45 crore in Q1 FY24, while revenue from operations rose 1.73%.
article_body:
Shree Cement Q1 Profit Down 51.3% to Rs 278.45 Crore

Share on:

By Rediff Money Desk, New Delhi Aug 06, 2024 13:57

Shree Cement's consolidated net profit declined by 51.31% to Rs 278.45 crore in Q1 FY24, while revenue from operations rose 1.73%.

Photograph: Amit Dave/Reuters

New Delhi, Aug 6 (PTI) Bangur family promoted Shree Cement Ltd on Tuesday reported a decline of 51.31 per cent in its consolidated net profit to Rs 278.45 crore for the first quarter ended June 2024.



The company had posted a net profit of Rs 571.94 crore in the April-June period a year ago, according to a regulatory filing from Shree Cement Ltd (SCL).



However, its revenue from operations was up 1.73 per cent to Rs 5,123.96 crore during the quarter under review, as against Rs 5,036.65 crore in the corresponding period of the preceding fiscal.



Total expenses of SCL increased 10.05 per cent to Rs 4,957.24 crore in the June quarter.



SCL's total income rose 1.12 per cent to Rs 5,263.09 crore in the June quarter.



Shree Cement is the third largest cement-making firm, owning brands such as Roofon, Bangur Power, Shree Jung Rodhak, Bangur Cement and Rockstrong.



Shares of Shree Cement Ltd on Tuesday were trading at Rs 519.60 apiece on BSE, up 1.82 per cent from the previous close.

Home » Market News » Shree Cement Q1 Profit Down 51.3% to Rs 278.45 Crore

headline: Driving Sustainability and Empowering Communities: Shree Cement’s Holistic Approach to CSR and Green Energy
description: In this interview with Mr Satish Chander, Chief Manufacturing Officer, Shree Cement, we delve into Shree Cement’s multifaceted approach to Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and sustainability. With a remarkable investment of ₹51.34 crore in CSR activities during the 2023-24 financial year, Shree Cement has positively impacted over 6.7 lakh individuals, addressing critical areas such as skill development, maternal health, and rural infrastructure.
article_body:
In an era where environmental sustainability and community empowerment are becoming increasingly significant, Shree Cement has emerged as a leader in aligning business growth with impactful social and ecological initiatives. From promoting renewable energy and water conservation to empowering women and supporting education and healthcare, the company’s CSR efforts have transformed lives and strengthened communities.

In this interview with Mr Satish Chander, Chief Manufacturing Officer, Shree Cement, we delve into Shree Cement’s multifaceted approach to Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and sustainability. With a remarkable investment of ₹51.34 crore in CSR activities during the 2023-24 financial year, Shree Cement has positively impacted over 6.7 lakh individuals, addressing critical areas such as skill development, maternal health, and rural infrastructure. We explore the key objectives, standout projects, and innovative practices that underscore the company’s commitment to creating a sustainable and inclusive future while advancing toward a 100% renewable energy goal under the RE100 initiative.

Scroll down to know how technology, environmental stewardship, and social responsibility converge to drive meaningful change, setting a benchmark for businesses nationwide.

Q. Shree Cement has made a significant investment of ₹51.34 crore in CSR initiatives during the 2023-24 financial year. Could you share more about the key objectives of these initiatives and how they align with the company's mission and vision?

A. At Shree Cement, we strongly believe in the importance of giving back to society and our CSR initiatives reflect this belief. With an investment of ₹51.34 crore in the 2023-24 financial year, we continue to focus on making a positive impact on the communities we serve. Our primary objectives are to promote inclusive growth, improve community well-being and support the global Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Through our CSR programs, we work to create self-reliant communities by prioritizing critical areas such as education, healthcare, sustainability and women empowerment. These efforts are not just about providing support today but about laying the foundation for a brighter, more sustainable future for everyone involved. Our holistic approach to community development also aligns closely with our commitment to environmental stewardship and social responsibility, values that are at the core of our mission and vision. By focusing on these areas, we aim to drive both social and economic progress, helping build resilient and thriving communities.

Q. With over 6.7 lakh individuals positively impacted, what are some of the standout projects that have driven this wide-reaching impact, and how do you measure the success of these programs?

A. Shree Cement’s CSR initiatives have positively impacted over 6.7 lakh individuals, demonstrating the widespread reach and effectiveness of our programs. Some of the standout projects include large-scale education initiatives, such as the upgrade of school infrastructure and the provision of essential teaching aids and educational materials. These efforts have created a more conducive environment for students to learn and grow, ultimately contributing to higher literacy rates in the areas we serve. In addition, we have contributed to the improvement of rural infrastructure, including the construction of vital roads and other essential community facilities that improve the quality of life for residents. Healthcare is another area of focus, with our mobile health vans providing vital services to remote and underserved areas. Our maternal care programs have helped ensure that pregnant women have access to the necessary care, contributing to improved health outcomes for mothers and babies alike. Another key initiative is our women empowerment programs, which offer skill development training in areas like stitching and beautician courses, as well as our Marriage Support Program. To measure the success of these programs, we track important metrics such as the number of lives impacted, tangible improvements in literacy rates, health outcomes and the overall quality of life. Feedback from the communities is also crucial, helping us understand the effectiveness of our initiatives and allowing us to continuously improve our efforts.

Q. Women empowerment and skill development are critical areas of focus for Shree Cement. Can you provide more details about the specific programs you have implemented in these areas and the tangible outcomes for the communities?

A. Shree Cement is deeply committed to empowering women and helping them achieve financial independence, which is why we have implemented a range of programs designed to provide women with the skills and resources they need to succeed. Through initiatives like stitching and beautician courses, we have equipped many women with valuable skills that enable them to generate a steady income, improving their household incomes and overall livelihoods. Beyond skill development, we have also launched the Marriage Support Program under Shree Samaj Sewa, which provides crucial financial assistance to Below Poverty Line (BPL) families for the marriages of their daughters. This program not only helps families alleviate the financial burden associated with marriage but also promotes social equity by supporting those in need. As a result of these initiatives, women have gained greater financial independence and a stronger voice in household decision-making. The programs have helped foster a sense of self-reliance, improving the socio-economic stability of families and contributing to the empowerment of women across our project areas. The tangible benefits of these programs can be seen in the growing participation of women in community activities and decision-making processes, helping to create more inclusive and equal communities.

Q. The healthcare initiatives, especially in maternal and child healthcare, appear to be an important focus. Could you elaborate on how these programs have improved health outcomes in the communities Shree Cement serves?

A. At Shree Cement, we understand the importance of health in creating thriving communities and that’s why we have placed a strong emphasis on improving maternal and child healthcare. Our healthcare initiatives are designed to address some of the most pressing health concerns in rural and underserved areas. We organize free health camps across various villages, where local residents can access medical consultations, treatments and necessary medicines at no cost. These camps have proven to be vital for people who otherwise might not have access to essential healthcare services. We also run immunization drives to protect children from preventable diseases and work to eradicate malnutrition in the areas where we operate. In addition, we have partnered with government bodies to enhance maternal care services, promoting institutional deliveries and raising awareness about the importance of maternal and child healthcare. Through these collaborations, we have been able to ensure that pregnant women in rural areas have access to skilled medical care, which has been crucial in reducing maternal and infant mortality rates. Our focus on adolescent healthcare also ensures that young people receive the necessary care and education to maintain their health. As a result of these initiatives, we have seen improved health outcomes, with better access to healthcare services and a stronger emphasis on preventative care. These efforts have contributed to healthier and more resilient communities, creating a foundation for long-term well-being.



Q. Sustainability is a key pillar of Shree Cement’s strategy, especially with a 55.9% green energy share. Can you discuss the company’s journey toward sustainability and the role these initiatives play in reducing your carbon footprint?

A. India’s rapid economic growth, marked by its emergence as the fifth-largest global economy, presents a critical challenge: driving industrial progress while protecting the environment. For the cement industry, the third-largest energy consumer in the country, this responsibility is immense. At Shree Cement, sustainability is deeply embedded in our operations, reflecting our commitment to reducing our carbon footprint and embracing clean energy solutions.

With 55.9% of our total power needs met through green energy, Shree Cement has established itself as a leader in the transition toward sustainable industrial practices. Our clinkerization plants are equipped with Waste Heat Recovery Systems (WHRS), which enable the conversion of waste heat into usable energy, significantly reducing our dependence on conventional power sources. Alongside WHRS, our renewable energy portfolio includes 219 MW of solar power and 56.3 MW of wind energy, bringing our total green energy capacity to 517 MW.

These initiatives represent more than technological advancements; they are a reflection of our responsibility toward the planet. By shifting away from coal and grid electricity, we achieve substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions while improving operational efficiency and reducing costs. This dual benefit aligns seamlessly with global decarbonisation goals and reinforces our commitment to Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) standards.

Q. Shree Cement is committed to the RE100 initiative and aims for 100% renewable electricity by 2050. How are you working towards this ambitious goal and what steps are being taken to ensure the success of this commitment?

A. Shree Cement’s commitment to achieving 100% renewable electricity by 2050 under the RE100 initiative is firmly rooted in a clear and focused strategy. By steadily increasing our renewable electricity capacity—now at 275.3 MW as of November 2024—we are making measurable progress toward this ambitious goal. This growth reflects our ongoing investments in solar and wind energy while maintaining our commitment to avoiding any new thermal power capacities. Additionally, more than 110 MW of renewable energy projects are in various stages of development with an approximate capital expenditure of ₹450 crore. Every step we take is guided by the principle of prioritizing clean sustainable energy solutions contributing to reducing our environmental footprint and advancing the global transition to renewable energy.

Q. Infrastructure development is a significant part of your CSR efforts. Can you provide examples of specific community infrastructure projects, such as sanitation, water access, and public utility spaces, and their impact on the quality of life in underserved areas?

A. Infrastructure development has been at the core of our efforts to uplift underserved communities and improve their quality of life. Through Shree Samaj Sewa, we have undertaken projects such as constructing toilets, providing safe drinking water facilities, developing public parks and enhancing rural roads and school buildings. These initiatives have had a significant impact, improving sanitation and health outcomes, boosting mobility and increasing access to education. By focusing on infrastructure that directly addresses the daily needs of communities, we aim to create lasting, positive change, fostering better living conditions and sustainable growth in the areas we serve.

Q. Shree Cement has made notable strides in environmental leadership. Could you expand on the company's efforts in water conservation and any innovative projects aimed at fostering environmental sustainability?

A. Water conservation has been a key focus area in our environmental sustainability efforts. We have undertaken rainwater harvesting projects at government schools and worked on deepening water bodies and ponds in villages to enhance water storage capacity. These initiatives have had a positive impact on groundwater recharge, helping to secure water resources for the local communities. Additionally, we actively support farmers by providing them with improved seeds, agricultural training and exposure to better crop management practices. This includes guidance on seed treatment, fertilizer use and sustainable farming techniques aimed at increasing productivity.

We also offer subsidies on agricultural equipment and provide high-yielding seeds, further empowering farmers to enhance their yields. To promote greenery and improve the local environment, we have distributed saplings to farmers, encouraging mass plantation efforts and boosting vegetation in nearby villages. Through these combined efforts, we strive to contribute to both environmental sustainability and the economic well-being of the communities we serve.

Q. How has Shree Cement's adoption of advanced technologies improved quality, efficiency and environmental impact in cement manufacturing, and how do these innovations contribute to the success of your CSR initiatives?

A. Our adoption of digital tools and technologies has transformed the way we manage resources, streamline operations, and boost productivity across the value chain. SAP’ integration has improved the quality of work from raw material handling to production and logistics, reducing waste and optimizing energy use. Real-time order management and communication through UdaanPRO and UdaanCONNECT have empowered sales within the teams and partners, ensuring greater efficiency in meeting market demands while reducing operational delays and emissions.

These technological advancements don’t just optimize our internal processes, they are instrumental in driving our Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives. By increasing operational efficiency, we’ve been able to direct more resources towards environmental sustainability and community empowerment. For example, our continuous investment in renewable energy now accounts for 55.9% of our energy consumption, reducing reliance on non-renewable sources and contributing to a cleaner environment. Furthermore, the technology enables better water management, with innovations in rainwater harvesting and wastewater recycling, allowing us to conserve vital resources and reduce our environmental footprint.

In terms of CSR impact, these technological developments enable us to allocate resources more effectively to key areas such as women empowerment, health and education, infrastructure development and supporting the families of martyred soldiers through Project Naman which is a tribute to the bravery of our armed and paramilitary forces, helping build homes for the dependents of martyrs. The enhanced efficiency and resource optimization mean that we can extend our reach and make a more significant difference in the communities we serve. Moreover, digital platforms help us stay in tune with community needs by enabling real-time feedback, ensuring that our CSR efforts are not only effective but also responsive to the evolving challenges faced by these communities.

headline: India’s Shree Cement posts 72.5% plunge in Q3 profit on weak demand, prices
description: (Reuters) - India's Shree Cement reported a slump third-quarter profit on Thursday, hurt by weak prices and a slowdown in activity in a seasonally weak period. The company's consolidated net profit
article_body:
The company’s consolidated net profit plunged 72.5% to 1.93 billion rupees ($22.3 million) in the quarter ended Dec. 31.

(Reuters) – India’s Shree Cement reported a slump third-quarter profit on Thursday, hurt by weak prices and a slowdown in activity in a seasonally weak period.

KEY CONTEXT

Cement prices have been falling for most of last year, including a 11% on-year drop in the December quarter, which is also a seasonally weak one as the pace of construction activity slows.

However, market leader UltraTech and its closest rivals, Adani Group-owned Ambuja and ACC, benefitted as their acquisition spree helped bolster volumes.

However, while UltraTech and ACC reported upbeat results, smaller companies such as Dalmia Bharat and Orient Cement succumbed to low prices.

headline: Shree Cement Shares Fall 2% Weak Q1 Earnings; Net Profit Falls 51%
description: Shares of Shree Cements were trading 2% lower on 6 August after the company announced its quarterly earnings for April-June.
article_body:
Shares of Shree Cement were trading 2% lower on 6 August after the company announced its quarterly earnings for April-June.

The cement major reported a 51% year-on-year decline in consolidated net profit to Rs 278.61 crore for the quarter under review from Rs 572.3 crore reported in the same quarter of the previous fiscal year.

The company’s revenue from operations during the quarter stood at Rs 5,123.9 crore, marking a marginal growth of 1.75% YoY against Rs 5,035.6 crore reported in the same quarter last year.

On the operating level, the company’s earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) slipped by 1.9% YoY to Rs 927 crore. In contrast, the EBITDA margins contracted by 70 basis points to 18.15 during Q1FY25 compared to 18.8% in Q1FY24.

However, the company’s total sales volume increased by 8% year over year to 9.64 million tonnes, compared to 8.92 million tonnes recorded last year during the same quarter.

During the quarter, the company commissioned its integrated cement unit in Andhra Pradesh, which has a production capacity of 3 million tonnes per annum.

In addition, the company is undertaking capacity expansions, with 6 million tonnes per annum (MTPA) in Rajasthan, 3 MTPA in Karnataka, 3.4 MTPA in Chhattisgarh, and 3 MTPA in Uttar Pradesh. These projects are progressing as planned.

At 3:30 pm, the shares of Shree Cement closed 2.74% lower at Rs 26,100 on NSE.

headline: India’s cement sector has significant opportunities to cut carbon intensity, boost efficiency: Satish Chan
description: While the cement sector globally is pushing for a greener future, India has significant opportunities to scale up its renewable energy integration, says Satish Chander, Chief Manufacturing Officer (CMO), Shree Cement.
article_body: India's cement industry is embracing sustainability as the world transitions to green energy. As the second-largest cement producer globally, India must address its significant carbon footprint. Satish Chander, Chief Manufacturing Officer at Shree Cement , shared the company's eco-friendly initiatives with ET Digital.Chander says Shree Cement has made notable strides in reducing its environmental impact. By harnessing waste heat recovery systems, the company has decreased its reliance on traditional energy sources. This innovative approach converts waste heat into electricity, yielding lower energy costs.Additionally, Shree Cement is pioneering the production of low-carbon cements, significantly mitigating the environmental effects of its manufacturing processes. Edited excerpts:At Shree Cement, nearly 56% of Shree Cement's power requirements for FY2023-24 were met through renewable energy, positioning the company as an industry leader in the Indian cement sector in terms of sustainability. The shift towards green energy is driven by a combination of strategies and technologies, including an energy portfolio of 480 MW from solar, wind and Waste Heat Recovery (WHR) systems. These technologies help reduce dependence on traditional power sources and significantly cut energy costs.Further bolstering this renewable energy shift, the company has already enhanced its green electricity capacity to 520 MW during the current financial year. The company is in the process of implementing an additional 110 MW of renewable energy capacity, with investments exceeding Rs 450 crore.India’s cement sector is among the largest in the world, with the country being the second-largest producer of cement globally. The challenge of carbon emissions is inherent to the cement manufacturing process. Shree Cement's efforts to reduce emissions, invest in renewable energy and pioneer low-carbon cement production put the company at the forefront of the Indian industry in its sustainability journey.While the cement sector globally is pushing for a greener future, India has significant opportunities to scale up its renewable energy integration, reduce carbon intensity and enhance efficiency.Shree Cement currently boasts a renewable energy portfolio of 520 MW, which includes a blend of solar, wind and Waste Heat Recovery (WHR) systems. These sources collectively account for more than 50% of the company’s total installed electricity capacity.In line with the commitment to achieve 100% renewable electricity by 2050 under the RE100 initiative, the company is investing Rs 450 crore in the development of an additional 110 MW of renewable capacity. In addition to solar and wind projects, Shree Cement is exploring emerging technologies like Battery Energy Storage and Pumped Hydro Energy Storage.Although green energy infrastructure can be capital-intensive, Shree Cement has effectively managed and controlled operational costs through strategic investments, technological innovations, and operational efficiencies. The company’s investment in Waste Heat Recovery (WHR) systems, for instance, has proven to be a cost-effective solution for generating electricity from the waste heat produced during cement manufacturing.By capturing and converting waste heat into electricity, Shree Cement has reduced its dependence on traditional energy sources, thereby lowering energy costs in the long run. Similarly, the use of captive solar and wind electricity reduces the dependence on external sources of electricity and provides substantial savings in energy costs. Additionally, the company’s focus on alternative fuels, such as agro waste, has helped reduce reliance on fossil fuels, further curbing operational expenses. In-house innovations, such as synthetic gypsum production using hazardous waste from other industries, also contribute to cost savings and resource optimisation.Low-carbon cements such as PPC ( Portland Pozzolana Cement ), PSC (Portland Slag Cement) and CC (Composite Cement) are crucial in reducing Shree Cement’s overall carbon emissions. These products replace a significant portion of clinker, the most energy-intensive component of traditional cement, with more sustainable cementitious alternatives like fly ash and slag. By lowering the reliance on clinker, these blended cements require less energy and less limestone to produce, which in turn reduces their carbon footprint.PPC incorporates fly ash, a by-product of coal combustion, helping to reduce both carbon emissions and landfill waste. PSC uses slag from steel manufacturing, which further cuts CO2 emissions by decreasing the need for clinker. CC substitutes both fly ash and slag for clinker, providing another option to lower carbon emissions in cement production.Through the production of these low-carbon cements, Shree Cement is significantly reducing the environmental impact of its manufacturing processes.Yes, Shree Cement has set ambitious sustainability targets to ensure that its growth is aligned with global climate goals and the company’s commitment to environmental stewardship. By 2030, the company aims to reduce its Scope 1 emissions by 12.7% and Scope 2 emissions by 27.1%, both compared to 2019 levels. These targets reflect Shree Cement’s proactive approach to lowering its carbon footprint and improving its sustainability performance.Additionally, we are determined to achieve zero waste to landfill and zero wastewater discharge from our manufacturing facilities every year. Looking ahead, the company has a goal to achieve 100% renewable electricity by 2050, in line with its participation in the RE100 initiative. The company is also focused on expanding its production capacity to over 80 MTPA by 2028.

headline: Shree Cements shares 1.46% as Sensex
description: A total of 87 shares changed hands on the counter till 01:23PM (IST)
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

Shares of the Shree Cements Ltd. traded at Rs 25946.15 on BSE at 01:23PM (IST) on Friday, 1.46 per cent from previous close.The scrip quoted a 52-week low price of Rs 23500.15 and a high of Rs 30710.15.Earlier, the stock saw a gap up opening in the morning.A total of 87 lakh shares changed hands on the counter till 01:23PM (IST).The stock of Shree Cements Ltd. commands a market value of Rs 93615.65 crore.The stock traded at a price-to-earning (P/E) multiple of 54.06, while the price-to-book value ratio stood at 4.48. Return on equity (ROE) was at 11.57 per cent, according to exchange data.In the BSE500 pack, 267 stocks traded in the green, while 232 stocks were in the red.Promoters held 62.55 per cent in the Shree Cements Ltd . as of 30-Sep-2024 while foreign portfolio investors and domestic institutional investors owned 10.39 per cent and 14.22 per cent, respectively.

headline: Shree Cements shares 1.14% as Nifty drops
description: A total of 143 shares changed hands on the counter till 11:22AM (IST).
article_body:
(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

NEW DELHI: Shares of Shree Cements Ltd. traded 1.14 per cent in Friday's trade at 11:22AM (IST). Around 143 shares changed hands on the counter.The counter opened at Rs 26750.00 and touched an intraday high and low of Rs 26945.05 and Rs 26335.10, respectively, in the session so far. The stock of Shree Cements Ltd. quoted a 52-week high of Rs 30710.15 and a 52-week low of Rs 23500.15.Total market cap of the Shree Cements Ltd . stood at Rs 95053.11 crore at the time of writing this report.The company reported consolidated net sales of Rs 4235.5500 crore for the quarter ended 30-Sep-2024, 19.52 per cent from previous quarter's Rs 5263.0900 crore and 14.12 per cent from the year-ago quarter's Rs 4932.1100 crore.The net for latest quarter stood at Rs 76.44 crore, 82.89 per cent from the same quarter a year ago.As of 30-Sep-2024, domestic institutional investors held 9.24 per cent stake in the company, while foreign institutional investors held 10.39 per cent and the promoters 62.55 per cent.According to BSE data, the stock traded at a P/E multiple of 54.89 and a price-to-book ratio of 4.48. A higher P/E ratio shows investors are willing to pay a higher price because of better future growth expectations. Price-to-book value indicates the inherent value of a company and is the measure of the price that investors are ready to pay even for no growth in the business. Shree Cements Ltd . belongs to the Cement - North industry.

headline: Shree Cement shares drop over 3% after 51% YoY decline in Q1 PAT. Should you invest?
description: Shree Cement faced a 4% drop in shares as it posted a 51% decrease in net profit for the June quarter, down to Rs 278.6 crore. Revenues saw a slight increase to Rs 5,123.9 crore, but higher expenses offset gains. Brokerages had varied opinions, noting concerns about weak demand and geographic expansion.
article_body:
Here is what brokerages say:







(You can now subscribe to our

(You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel

Shares of Shree Cement on Thursday fell 4% on BSE to its day’s low of Rs 24,234.15 after the company reported a 51% year-on-year (YoY) decline in its net profit for the June quarter to Rs 278.6 crore.The company reported a net profit of Rs 572.3 crore for the corresponding quarter of the last financial year.Meanwhile, the revenue from operations stood at Rs 5,123.9 in the June quarter of FY25, up by 1.75% from Rs 5,035.6 crore reported in the year-ago period.The company's total expenses in the June quarter grew by 4.4% to Rs 4,618, up from Rs 4,422 in Q1FY24. In the previous quarter, the total expenses were reported at Rs 4,438 crore.Nomura maintained a buy call on Shree Cement with a target price of Rs 33,400.Q1 results’ lower-than-expected blended realization leads to an EBITDA miss while the capacity expansion is on track to reach 74MT by FY26F.Motilal Oswal has maintained a neutral view on the stock with a target price of Rs 27,500.The domestic brokerage firm stated that it continues to believe that most of the company’s expansions focus on existing markets (North, East, and part of South), while a large part of Central India and West will remain untapped until FY27E. Management indicated that cement demand will remain weak until CY24-end, which will also adversely impact prices.Emkay Global maintained an add rating on the stock with a target price of Rs 27,300.Change in the geographical mix (with increased share in the East), higher lead distance (+21km QoQ), and stabilization cost for new plants have impacted profitability in the quarter. The management also expects demand/prices to remain subdued in the near term and to improve Q4FY25 onward.Nuvama has retained its hold rating on Shree Cement with a revised target price of Rs 27,022, from an earlier Rs 28,373Shree Cement delivered robust volume growth (up 8% YoY) in Q1FY25 while the EBITDA at Rs 916 crore missed the estimate by 24% due to lower-than-expected blended realisation (down 6% QoQ versus 3% for industry), partly due to a change in geographical mix. The company’s capex plan might help deliver sustained volume growth while cost efficiency measures would allow it to sustain cost leadership in the cement industry.

article_metadata.description: Shree Cement faced a 4% drop in shares as it posted a 51% decrease in net profit for the June quarter, down to Rs 278.6 crore. Revenues saw a slight increase to Rs 5,123.9 crore, but higher expenses offset gains. Brokerages had varied opinions, noting concerns about weak demand and geographic expansion.

description: बलौदाबाजार. जिले के श्री सीमेंट कंपनी को कलेक्टर ने नोटिस जारी कर 7 दिन के भीतर जवाब मागा हैं. मामला स्कूली बच्चों के तबियत खराब होने से जुड़ा हुआ है. इसके
